metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: The <any> element enables us to extend the XML document with elements not specified by the schema!
content.html: The <any> element enables us to extend the XML document with elements not specified by the schema!

content.text: The <any> element enables us to extend the XML document with elements not specified by the schema.
content.html: The <any> element enables us to extend the XML document with elements not specified by the schema.

content.text: The following example is a fragment from an XML schema called "family.xsd". It shows a declaration for the "person" element. By using the <any> element we can extend (after <lastname>) the content of "person" with any element:
content.html: The following example is a fragment from an XML schema called "family.xsd". It shows a declaration for the "person" element. By using the <any> element we can extend (after <lastname>) the content of "person" with any element:

content.code:
<xs:element name="person">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:any minOccurs="0"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="person">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="firstname" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="lastname" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:any minOccurs="0"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

content.text: Now we want to extend the "person" element with a "children" element. In this case we can do so, even if the author of the schema above never declared any "children" element.
content.html: Now we want to extend the "person" element with a "children" element. In this case we can do so, even if the author of the schema above never declared any "children" element.

content.text: Look at this schema file, called "children.xsd":

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
targetNamespace="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
elementFormDefault="qualified">


<xs:element name="children">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="childname" type="xs:string"

maxOccurs="unbounded"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>


</xs:schema>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
targetNamespace="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
elementFormDefault="qualified">

<xs:element name="children">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="childname" type="xs:string"
      maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

</xs:schema>

content.text: The XML file below (called "Myfamily.xml"), uses components from two different schemas; "family.xsd" and "children.xsd":
content.html: The XML file below (called "Myfamily.xml"), uses components from two different schemas; "family.xsd" and "children.xsd":

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>


<persons xmlns="http://www.microsoft.com"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.microsoft.com family.xsd
https://www.w3schools.com children.xsd">


<person>


<firstname>Hege</firstname>


<lastname>Refsnes</lastname>


<children>


<childname>Cecilie</childname>


</children>

</person>


<person>


<firstname>Stale</firstname>


<lastname>Refsnes</lastname>

</person>


</persons>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<persons xmlns="http://www.microsoft.com"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.microsoft.com family.xsd
https://www.w3schools.com children.xsd">

<person>
  <firstname>Hege</firstname>
  <lastname>Refsnes</lastname>
  <children>
    <childname>Cecilie</childname>
  </children>
</person>

<person>
  <firstname>Stale</firstname>
  <lastname>Refsnes</lastname>
</person>

</persons>

content.text: The XML file above is valid because the schema "family.xsd" allows us to extend the "person" element with an optional element after the "lastname" element.
content.html: The XML file above is valid because the schema "family.xsd" allows us to extend the "person" element with an optional element after the "lastname" element.

content.text: The <any> and <anyAttribute> elements are used to make EXTENSIBLE documents! They allow documents to contain additional elements that are not declared in the main XML schema.
content.html: The <any> and <anyAttribute> elements are used to make EXTENSIBLE documents! They allow documents to contain additional elements that are not declared in the main XML schema.
